newsitem.title: USA: Most Americans upbeat on economy - poll.
newsitem.headline: Most Americans upbeat on economy - poll.

text.p: Most Americans say the economy is getting better, the first time under President Clinton the outlook has been that positive, USA Today reported Wednesday.
According to a USA Today/CNN/Gallup poll, 50 percent of Americans feel the United States is on the right track for the 21st century, against 41 percent who say it is not.
In addition, 45 percent are satisfied with the way things are going in the United States, sharply up from 14 percent in June 1992.

Fifty-nine percent say the economy is getting better, up from 39 percent in May and 29 percent in September 1992, when George Bush was seeking a second term. Thirty-seven percent say the economy is getting worse.
Only 31 percent of those interviewed said they supported Republican presidential candidate Bob Dole's economic plan, which includes a tax cut. That is down from 51 percent on Aug 18.
The poll involved 1,009 registered voters interviewed by telephone from Aug 30 to Sept 1. It has a margin of error of 3 percentage points.
